Also Anthony David's is BYOB so I'd save on the alcohol markup. I'm thankful that a place like Elysian that is kid-friendly exists but that still isn't an excuse for mediocre quality food.

Ate here for lunch on a Friday after weeks of passing the place. I wish I'd stopped by sooner!Attentive, if a little impersonal, service, but the food was on point. I had the grilled chicken sandwich with field greens, which was surprisingly (but pleasantly) light -- the salad dressing was more olive oil than balsamic (which I prefer), and the herb mayo on the sandwich wasn't heavy (i.e., fatty) in the slightest. Even the bacon was nice and thin (but delicious).Great little spot on Washington. Can't speak for dinner service, but it's a nice midday meal spot.

I'll admit, a visit to Hoboken during the annual Lepre-Con celebration wasn't one of my better ideas. But quickly venturing away from the green-clad, stumbling masses eventually allowed me to happen upon this fun, little place further north. I'll also admit, Elysian's initial appeal was that it wasn't a participant in the daily tomfoolery and there was no line to get inside, both big pluses after walking for awhile.I found a lone, empty stool at the end of the bar and decided on a Hoegaarden for some afternoon refreshment. The crowd was a nice mix of older folk with younger kids and there were a few college B-Ball games playing out on the screens above the bar.  Feeling slightly hungry, I eventually ordered the highly praised French Onion soup, which was a delicious warm-up on such a cold and windy day.Eventually, I somehow ended up getting free shots of Jameson and talking sports with the group of lively gentlemen next to me, an unexpected, yet entertaining way to cap off the afternoon. It certainly beat dealing with the drunken stupidity to the south.

I am in shock that Elysian is a "sister" restaurant to Amanda's. Elysian Cafe COMPLETELY blows Amanda's out of the water!! (see also: my two 2-star reviews of Amanda's)My boyfriend and I had our day-early Valentine's Day dinner here and oh-my-god the food was incredible. We started with their soup of the day, a tomato ginger. It had the consistency of a bisque - creamy, rich and bursting with flavor. I scraped the bowl clean and could have had another!!For my entree I had the pan-seared Alaskan cod. It was served over butternut squash risotto with green beans in a vinagrette-type dressing.  the whole thing was TO DIE for. The cod was cooked perfectly - fall apart, melt in your mouth consistency and so flavorful. The risotto, forget it. Words can't even do it justice. My boyfriend had the Crispy Pork Cutlet with Sour Cream and Herb Mashed Potatoes. He loved it. I tried a few bites, and the pork was delicious, the mashed potatoes even better. We were so incredibly full, but could not pass up on dessert. We split the white chocolate cheesecake with an Oreo cookie crust and then rolled each other home. Good thing we live close by.

I was not impressed with the Elysian Cafe. Perhaps we just visited on a night that was too crowded, but our experience was mediocre.  We left our name with the hostess, requesting an indoor table because it was quite chilly outside. She told us the wait would be 45 minutes, but when we returned 45 minutes later she told us we'd have to site outside.  We did so but made a bit of a stink. and they eventually moved us inside.The interior was fairly cramped. The back room was lit with some odd blue lighting, giving the room a bit of an unpleasant and sterile feel, in my opinion.Food was fine but not exceptional, and for the price it should have been much better. My NY Strip was disappointingly tough. My experience seems at odds with those others have had here based on the ratings, so perhaps I'll give Elysian another change some time.

I've never been disappointed with this place, no matter when I come. They have a solid brunch, lunch, and dinner menu. Awesome decor inside, and nice little terrace outside for warmer weather. Best Fish & Chips in town!

Stopped in for lunch at the Elysian. A wee bit muggy outside, we sat inside the velvet curtains within the reach of the a/c. Our waitress was pleasant, attentive, and quick to get us water and our drinks. I got the BLT, my friend, the grilled cheese. Half of either would have been more than enough. The bacon must have been 1/4" thick when they put it in the pan, it was easily 3/16" per slice and there must have been at least six slices piled on the BLT. I could only eat half. All in all a fine little old school bar/restaurant, I'd be interested in coming back for the live music I heard they have on weekends.
5 star brunch. I've brunched all over Hoboken and this has to be my favorite. Food was delicious, service was prompt. Great value, good atmosphere. Eggs florentine was amazing.

Delicious food. Always fresh.  My favorite place for breakfast or lunch. If you are coming for a weekend brunch on a nice day try to get there before 11am to avoid waiting. There is beautiful garden style seating. One of my favorite items on the brunch menu is the eggs benedict.  I get it with the French fries and a bellini. Service is always friendly and attentive.

I really loved it here! They are dog friendly and have delicious French fries. I tried my bff's Mac and cheese and it was really tasty. I had the grilled chicken sandwich and it was huge. I enjoyed it and the thick cut slab bacon was a huge plus. I will definitely be back!

Their service was top notch and the food incredible. I like that they give the option of a salad rather than fries with a sandwich. It was yummy and fresh. We ordered a burger and the croque and both were the best we've ever had.  Would go back time and time again.

Always a solid choice for an uptown brunch or lunch. The place is modeled after a French bistro, but with the old world charm if early 1900s Hoboken. The food is solid, and the only real complaint is outside they pack the tables super, super close. Either way, it's part of my regular rotation.

The Elysian has the best brunch in Hoboken.  Their steak and eggs are to die for.  The outdoor patio is very pleasant, green and flowery, it has a European chic feel to it.The staff is quite nice, and the restaurant itself is a part of the community.  During Sandy they were open even though power was out and everyone ate by the candle light.  They did not price gouge either.  It was one of the more memorable dinners I had in Hoboken.

I had a pretty average experince at Elysian Cafe.  Came here on a Saturday and was able to sit outside...which was nice until I waited about 15 minutes until someone helped us.  Ok.. finally ordered and got the egg white veggie omelette with home fries and friend ordered the three cheese omlette.  It was pretty basic... the home fries were kind of cold and plain and the three cheese was super tiny.  Then the waitress spilled 3 drinks on us by accident, which they comp'd our mimosas in the end so I give them a few points for that.  Needless to say I was still hungry afterwards and went straight to get somthing more substantial to eat.

Had a terrible experience here today for brunch. The food was fine, but the service was just horrible. We sat down brunch around 2 pm, the hostess and all wait staff had the most appalling attitude and facial expressions. The hostess did not smile once while seating us and everyone else that I saw. Waiter and waitress just the same. Did some one call a staff meeting and yell at everyone??All in all the food isn't that spectacular to make up for the uncomfortable service.

Elysian Cafe always has intrigued me. The outside area is beautiful with flowering pots and cast iron tables and chairs. The french like decor, and amazing menu made this the place for a celebratory lunch. We sat outside. The wait staff was amazing. Super friendly and on their a game. I went with the salmon club. Thick layers of salmon with avocado and a creme like topping, sandwiched between white toast. There was so much salmon, I couldn't even eat it all. Was a little too much. To be honest. It came with salad or fries, I went with a salad that was plentiful. $13.75.My guest ordered the lunch special: French Onion Soup and Roast Beef Poivre sandwich (1/2). Amazing. The French Onion soup came out in a mug with steaming, melted cheese everywhere. I sampled it and was a pretty damn good taste. Her roast beef sandwich was large though it was only half and it looked phenomenal. All this for a price tag of $9. I would definitely get this option next time. I peeped a few dinner specials which I definitely want to come check out and regardless, want to come check this place out again for more lunch and for dinner!

Went there couple months ago not sure why I didn't leave any review since then. Food was ok as far as I remember but wasn't my type. On the other hand my wife was a happier person. Didn't go back since then !

We tend to go here in the summer only. The food is average to pretty good, depending on what you order, but the outside seating on a summer night with a nice glass of wine or a craft beer boosts my rating. The inside back room has very strange lighting and bad acoustics that generally keep me away in colder weather. As for the food - The key lime pie is quite yummy.  The cod entree is always a reliable choice and seems to change seasonally as to the risotto and accompany sauce. The burger is also a good standard option as are the mussels. The Parmesan truffle fries can be fantastic, but I've also had them when they are kinda soggy. I'm a sucker for lobster rolls, but theirs looks to be loaded with mayo.

Went here on a date and its perfect for that. Its a really cute set-up. Very romantic and intimate. I also stopped in real quick for a drink with friends on a Saturday night. They had a girl playing live music on a guitar. The lighting and atmosphere is great... very cute spot
Delicious Salmon benedict, an excellent choice for a weekend brunch

I like Elysian Cafe because it feels like a local restaurant that you know things will not go wrong. Like: atmosphere, friendly services, food was served in decent time even though the place was packed, good value for what you get, desertDislike: nothing in particular, but I'd suggest you to make reservation as it's very popular and the waiting time can be a little long. 4 of us came here on a Saturday night without reservation, we waited at the bar for 25 mins, which was not bad. But the bar area was quite small and crowded, so it would be difficult to stand around for more than 30 mins. Food generally was good, maybe not outstanding but certainly it wouldn't disappoint you. We had:Starters: butternuts squash soup (yummy), Calamari and Mizuna Salad, Mains: cods & steaks Sides: mashed potato, fries, Desert: cheese cakeI really enjoyed the cod and mashed potato, my friends thought the steaks were decent. What stood out was the cheese cake, it was absolutely delicious!The bill came in very reasonable, I would totally come back again!

This is one of my favorite places in Hoboken. When it's warm it's so nice to eat outside for lunch with a coworker or friend. The food is amazing and I cannot get over the quality of their salmon! If you don't like to sit outside don't fret because the inside is so beautifully decorated and ornate you will have just as great of an experience! It is difficult to get in some times and each time I've been there my estimated wait time is severely underestimated. Overall, the wait is worth it.

Elysian! It's been a while. Good to see you again.On Sunday (06/22), my boyfriend and I stopped here for a way-too-late-meal-to-be-considered-brunch (it was just after 3 when we got there), and since the weather was absolutely gorgeous, we decided to sit outside. Our server (I think his name was John) came out almost immediately and seemed quite amused at my boyfriend's lack of decisiveness, but he was a genuinely nice guy and made some very astute suggestions on what to order (he dismissed the croquette as "just a ham sandwich" and praised the steak sandwich to the skies).For our entrees, I decided on the smoked salmon club, which was an impressive set of four small triple-decker sandwiches with huge helpings of delicious salmon, avocado, dill sauce, and fresh lettuce. I assumed I would get the pommes frites as my side, but I was surprised when John offered the option of salad instead, so I went with that and was rewarded with a hearty portion of vibrant romaine and red leaf lettuce, drizzled in a balsamic reduction dressing. I also had a glass of Cabernet with my meal, which helped bring out the smoky flavor of the salmon. My boyfriend ordered the highly recommended Elysian Steak Sandwich and was quite pleased with it. I tried a piece of the steak and liked it; it was cooked medium but was not chewy or hard.  I willed myself to stay away from his pommes frites, however. Those things should come with a warning label for extreme deliciousness.I'm glad to see The Elysian Cafe step up its game from my last visit, and I will definitely be back for more good food.

What a cute place. If you want a quaint little café for a quiet weekend brunch or lunch and want to feel a little like you're in Europe, this is your place. Besides the fact that the food is great, the atmosphere is so cute. I felt like I stepped back in time for a couple hours. Service was attentive and friendly- even when it was super busy we didnt wait more than 5 minutes for a table. I recommend the Elysian café!

Most beautiful looking restaurant in Hoboken. If it's not very cold they have beautiful flowers always blooming. The brunch is amazing and so is the dinner. Whenever friends are visiting from out of town I always try and take them here because it truly is such a one of a kind place!
Cutest little cafe on Washington St! Very friendly staff and great food.

Is it the best or most authentic French Bistro I've ever been to? No. I mean they serve Fish and Chips.. But it's a great, charming place to get gourmet variety in Hobokes.  I came here on a Monday w/ 2 gfs.  No res needed- around 7:30 it wasn't too packed, but we had to sit in one of the bar tables (kinda cramped). What's amazing about Elysian is that on Mondays they do a 2 for 1 special from the bar menu, where the lowest price entree is free! :).  My two friends ordered wine, which I think was $7-9 (they have happy hour though, 4-7!)Portions are huge here!  The service is great too- our waitress was nice and checked up on us.  Our food took a little while to come out though.  My one friend and I ordered the Moule Frites in White Wine Garlic Sauce w/ Pomme Frites.  The mussels could have been a bit..fresher (they were a bit rubbery?) but overall, this was very good. I loved the white wine garlic sauce.  It was so good with the pieces of garlic bread that came with it.  The meh item was the fries- they were skinny McDonald's-y fries that could have been better salted/seasoned but fortunately..they weren't too greasy. They were actually a bit dry.  Overall, the dish was a lot of food for $14. Our other friend ordered a french onion soup (very cheesy and plentiful).  This is one of their specialties, I think.  She then got the Chicken Club sandwich with salad, which was so big she had to pack one half for later! :) Bar entrees are in the mid teens- very reasonable for the food you get.  But for the more gourmet items, you can try their Dinner Menu which features steak, roasted chicken breast, and really nice fish.  Their menu has so much variety that I'd definitely come back to try it again- esp. for this Monday special :D The place has a larger dining room that is suitable for groups and dates.

My wife & I visited the Elysian Cafe for brunch and had a wonderful time. We sat at the bar because it was a long wait for a table, but that was just fine with us. I had the egg white omelet with spinach, tomatoes, and goat cheese, with pommes frites on the side. She had eggs florentine also w/ pommes frites. We both loved our meals and would definitely return the next time we're in Hoboken.

This is my go-to restaurant for brunch on weekends! They are moderately priced and the service is pretty good. The drinks are made very well and I have never had to wait for a table or a seat at the bar. This restaurant reminds me of the cafes in Paris, which makes sense since it is a French-American restaurant. Highly recommend.

Solid place with great service.  If you order food from the bar menu it usually comes out super fast.  Love the roast beef sandwich!  The fries are really good too.  The mussels are great.  The dinner entrees are just ok.  I've had most of the entrees on the menu and have never been crazy about any of them.  They have "steak night" on Wednesdays which is a pretty good deal but again the food is somewhat average.  Always good beers on tap and great bartenders.  Cool bar area (though cramped, especially when it's crowded) and a nice dining room.  I love the décor and the attention to detail.  And they have live music once in a while on weekends...usually local blues or folk bands.  Good brunch too (though a bit pricey).One thing I don't like about this place is the way some of the people who hang out here are kind of snobby.  Expect to hear conversations around you with people talking about how much money they just made on their latest deal, or how they are planning a trip to the latest European elitist hotspot.  And don't accidentally rub up against anyone around you, even if it's crowded, because these people seem to get offended easily.  Happened to me twice.  Get over yourselves people...you're at a bar.

Just the place we were looking for that day for brunch. Good food, outdoor seating, and good service. This was a nice choice. Has a European cafe feel and it was pleasant enjoying beautiful weather outside while having a tasty meal.

The dreaded 1 star...which really means minus a star because you f*cked up.  I've had some good experiences here.  They are a high volume brunch establishment which means they are doing some things right.  The food is pretty good.  That being said, a high volume eatery needs a high intensity staff that are on the ball at all times.  We entered around 10:45 on a Saturday ready to eat.  We were seated at an awkward table with a sun glare.  Without sunglasses, you would not be able to see your friends and would burn up.  It was disturbing, but we cannot control the heavens.  The server came around and we alerted her to our displeasure with the table.  She nodded and took our drink order...one water, one seltzer.  I eventually couldn't take the radiation seats any longer, and I got up to talk to our server who was talking to another group that wanted to change their seat for the same reason.  I reminded her that I had asked fifteen minutes ago to move outside of the radioactive zone. She responded, "he just requested that table in the shade".  I had requested it fifteen minutes ago.  Defeated I walked to my seat in the microwave.  Upset and starting to sweat, I couldn't order.  I could see that my guest was also not amused by the charade that was going on neither.  I told her that we were leaving as I put on my coat.  Nothing could prepare me for what happened next.We were both shaking our heads about the lack of concern and direct disregard to change tables as I see a waitress running after me with a guest check.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME?  she wanted money for club soda.  Water with carbon dioxide in it? Really????  I know that she didn't want the money...It was the scumbag managers so I wouldn't be too hard on her for doing her job.I asked her if she is serious and opened my wallet and asked her if a $5 bill would cover it?  Never EVER again with this low life establishment!  You do not treat a customer like shit and chase him for money for water with bubbles in it..DISGUSTING!  Also the bathroom is gross, and I never eat a place with a dirty bathroom.   The cooks relieve themselves in that same bathroom with no paper towels.

I had brunch here last Sunday, and it was wonderful. They have a beautiful area where you can eat outside, and it didn't hurt that it was the most gorgeous day out. We had the salmon eggs Benedict and the cinnamon-amaretto french toast along with coffee and mimosas. both entrees came with these little buckets of fries...when I say little...I mean NOT so little, considering we didn't even eat through half of what was in each bucket! Yum! The salmon eggs Benedict was delicious. The eggs were poached perfectly, and the smoked salmon was not too smoked/fishy tasting, so you know it was fresh. I could have stood for more hollandaise sauce on top though. The french toast was also very yummy. It was a little dry, but the maple syrup took care of that! The flavors weren't too much or too little, just the right amount of everything. Next time, I think I will ask for some fruit on the side! The plating of both dishes was well done. Our server was sweet, attentive, and on her game, especially considering how busy it was. I believe for the two of us to eat, our bill was under $40 before tip. Definitely worth it!

Good food, not a very fun staff to be around. I ordered a Sprite and it was watered down so I sent it back and asked for a coke but I had to remind the waitress after 20 minutes to get the coke. Overall good food, bad staff.

This place is great.  What a great job they do all around.  The ceilings you can stare at all day.  Drinks are impeccable.   Bartenders do a great job.   Service is great unless you get the tall white guy with the enormous attitude.  Your better of asking for a new server.  This guy will make you feel like your doing him a favor going to the place.  He needs a new profession..   Not serving people.   That's what you do.  Serve people.  Do it better.  "You got it" isn't a proper answer unless you work at taco bell.  Definitely not #ironshiekclass #makeyouhumble   He's worked there for over a year so I'm not sure why he still has a job.  Owners should know..

My bf and I tried this place while walking around in the neighborhood. We sat in the front, next to the bar and the door. Waitress was really nice and friendly and the place seems to be really busy and upbeat. We ordered the mussels and the fried calamari along with drinks (draft beer). The food was good, though there was nothing really special about it. Just two typical dishes. The place itself feels vintage and cozy. I would recommend this place for a typical dinner out but I'm not sure if I would bring anyone I wanted to impress here.
The BLT on the bar menu blew me away.  The thickness and amount of bacon paired with the avocado just sunk in my mouth.  Never wrote a review ever for food and I just had to share this.

Came here for brunch this weekend.  Sat outside because it was beautiful out, and while the setting was nice and quaint, the chairs were ungodly uncomfortable lol  You had to lean a certain way to find a comfortable balance.  There was no wait which was great, and our waitress was very nice.  Though, I ordered a bloody mary and she handed me a mimosa, & she recommended the fries vs potatoes wedges (said they were amazing), and they had absolutely no flavor watsoever.  I ordered the salmon eggs benedict which was very yummy.  My boyfriend ordered some pancakes & sausage and, disappointingly so, he literally got 1 little piece of sausage cut down the middle.  His food was fine.  Probably won't come here again when there are so many other options in Hoboken, but it was okay.
Awesome brunch. Steak and eggs, chicken sandwich, and eggs benedict are all very good. Highly recommend.

Starting to love Elysian again... "Old reliable."  Always a good meal inside at the bar or out on the patio. Good stuff for brunch, lunch, or dinner. And a great place to stop by for a drink from a friendly bartender. Try the Steak salad, salmon, lobster roll, fried calamari, grilled cheese, BLT + fried egg... So yeah, everything.

I have recommended Elysian cafe to a few people and enjoy the food and atmosphere.  However, I was very disappointed with a recent experience.  I brought my coworker here around 4:30 on a week day because I knew they had happy hour (it says it on the menu). We walked in and the place was empty so we were told to sit wherever.  We sat at a small table right next to the bar.  When the waiter came to take our oder we asked which wines were included in the happy hour (pointing to the happy hour note on the menu). The waiter told us which ones - and we each got a glass of pinot grigio.  Later when we got our check they charged us full price for the wine.  We asked because we clearly were in the happy hour time and the waiter told us that we had to sit at the bar to get the deal.  I think this was sneaky because we specifically asked the waiter what wine was included in the happy hour deal and he answered!  He should have told us then that we needed to switch to the bar - because we easily could have done it since we were the only people in the place.  We ended up just paying the bill, but this experience has made me think twice about recommending Elysian Cafe and I honestly haven't been back since.
It was ok.  Nice egg, nice Bloody Mary, nice day outside.  I was alittle hungry when I left but hey, it's not a diner.   Good service, the waiter was nice and kept coming over with water.

Elysian Cafe appears to be a little hoity-toity when you first look at it from the outside. Back in the day, before we tried them, I think my boyfriend and I avoided it for that reason. One day we went for lunch or brunch and we've been addicted ever since. We circle the block desperately looking for a parking spot in Hoboken even on a cold winter's day just so we can eat there.We feel acceptable arriving in t-shirt and jeans. I noticed the other day the hostess was dressed very casually. The interior is classy. Old fashioned antique ceilings. The thick dramatic curtain in front of the door always impressed me. Makes you feel less like a pig when you're stuffing a cheeseburger into your face. A pig with a pearl necklace on.I can't remember ever having an issue with the wait staff. They've always been pleasant.Their prices for most menu items are okay but they can be a little steep for certain items. We usually come for brunch when they have a nice discount on drinks. I recommend their Bloody Mary. Their coffee has been enjoyed by me many times. I've had the Steak and Eggs, Eggs Florentine, Eggs Benedict, Egg White Omelet, Salmon Eggs Benedict...I might be missing one. All delicious. Pick the french fries over the lyonnaise potatoes though--sad looking and not a lot of taste to them. The french fries are DIVINE. Think high class McDonald's fries. One time we went crazy and ordered the cheese plate. I don't think we'll do it again any time soon because it cost $12 but we did enjoy it.We came for dinner a time or two. I ordered the Pan Roasted Salmon one of those times. Really delicious. Their burger is also great even though it's bigger than my head and I have a hard time eating it without looking ridiculous.On warm days we love to eat outdoors if there are any seats left. Elysian Cafe is always busy when we come on the weekends. Lately we've been seated in the back area. The first time it smelled like sweat back there for some reason. I couldn't help but keep thinking that the guys in the kitchen must be sweating profusely and I was smelling their bodies. It didn't help my appetite. There were little kids nearby though...maybe they were the smelly ones. While we're on the topic of kids I don't understand why people bring small children here. The restaurant welcomes them...but I don't think they should. Not because I hate kids or anything. It just doesn't seem appropriate for this kind of place? Doesn't go with the flow. A couple of times we were seated right by a table of loud brats and their self absorbed parents so that could be poisoning my judgement.Privileged Hoboken children aside we will be returning for some time to come I expect.

Good service and they know how to make a brunch....fresh, good presentation...in the summer sit outside with some bubbly and enjoy the parade of double wide stroller families  (annoying as hell) and the yoga pant wearing granola eating mothers... hopefully you don't sit next to a few. It's likely the only bad part of this place (not their fault) honestly keep them home... too small of a space.

Elysian Cafe is so warm and charming. I love the ambience. The food never fails. Dinner (steak wednesdays, hellooooo) and the brunch ($6 cocktails and eggs Benedict - enough said). Nothing short of amazing. Plus, the prices are reasonable.

I walked in to be seated and asked a waiter who was not with any customers where I could find the hostess. His answer to me was "by the door!" in a 'you stupid' tone of voice rolling his eyes. Thanks! If I saw someone there I wouldn't have asked! If there was a host stand I would've waited there! You have 3 seperate seating areas (outside, front bar area, back dining area). Chill out. Everyone else was fairly pleasant. The amaretto French toast is good but I don't need to go back for it because I don't need to eat in a bad mood. It's not as if this area is lacking in other places to eat.
Food was okay, service was okay - overall just an okay experience. Would be willing to try brunch there when I'm in the area

Amazing brunch.  The salmon eggs benedict is amazing along with their French Toast.  Cool looking restaurant.  The staff is very friendly Ave their coffee is very good.  The place is small so you might have to wait a while to get in but it is worth it.

I really enjoy the Elysian. It is one of the only places I bring out-of-towners-- my mother included, who is tough to please-- because of the restaurant's consistency as an establishment. The waitstaff is always friendly, and the food is nice and always out in a timely manner. I have only had a bad experience at the Elysian perhaps once, and that was on a day when they were clearly short staffed (it was a holiday, if I remember correctly). My out-of-town friend griped, but it was really a one time thing. I suppose what I like the best about the Elysian is that I know what to expect. However, that isn't to say the dishes or atmosphere are boring alternatives to Hoboken's other places-- it is always quite lively when it should be (i.e. During a busy dinner) and quiet when it should be (i.e on a Wednesday afternoon). My mom loves the smoked salmon sandwich, my best friend swears by the tacos and the steak sandwich, and the mussels are great, too. Oh! And the French onion soup-- yum.

Decided to try their brunch and we enjoyed it very much. My husband had the french toast which he loved and I had eggs benedict without the bread. It was a lovely summer morning, sat outside, customer service was good. Would come back again for brunch!

Went to brunch today.  Not very busy.  Server came to the table and didn't say anything other than raised his eyebrows. No greeting at all.  I made the assumption he wanted my order so we ordered our brunch. I ordered eggs Benedict which came out tepid.  The potatoes which were recommend were dry and inedible.  My partner ordered a Croque Madame which turned out to be an egg sandwich also served almost cold.  The most lively part of this restaurant was the banter among the servers talking about their previous nights entertainment.  Needless to say I will never go here again.  If you're smart you'll stay away also.
Consistently amazing food. Been here a dozen times or so. Get the garlic fries with truffle oil and the skirt steak for happiness!

The fact that they have been around for so long is proof of their great food and service for a reasonable price. I have been here for breakfast, lunch and dinner and been pleasantly surprised each time.

Good reasonable experience with a lot on the plate. Great food, and atmosphere is always a plus. Really like this neighbor every day place, focus on having diners coming back. The staff is professionally trained, with the exception of a couple of small accidents easy resolved with a smile and a comp. It's def an Hoboken institution.

Stopped in for a drink.  The bar area is beautiful.  The food I saw being served to other patrons looked appetizing and generous.  I'm going back for a meal....However, it was worth visiting just for to the 1895 feel of the place.

One of my favorite places to eat. I've lived in Montclair my entire life and grew up with an elite taste of food. I've recently moved to Hoboken and ate at the Elysian and it was just as good quality as any restaurant in Montclair or NYC. For those Montclair-ites it will be my new Raymond's.

I'm a fan.  Yes it's a little pricy, and if I'm gonna spend it I think I'd prefer Amanda's, but this is definitely a great neighborhood spot, the kind of place where if you're a regular everybody knows your name.  I had the baked cod and it was really good. I am tempted to go 4 stars on it..... And on their affordable wine list.  Siting outside is boss too.

Ive never written a review for food before but i felt compelled to come on here for the good of humanity. i mistakenly reserved a spot on valentines day (mind you, i knew the fixed course menus anywhere on valentines day would be subpar, but i figure, how bad could it be?) well, let me tell you friends. for an absolutely absurd price, you can get 5 fried oysters in spicy mayo, 4 small slices of skirt steak, and 2 cold crepes. id also like to emphasize that ive donated to soup kitchens before and ive tried their food. the meal was on par with 2 of them and im pretty sure the one in new haven had far better food than elysian. it was crystal clear the ownership was trying to wring every penny out of this holiday and i was just a sucker along for the ride. do yourself a favor and dont make the same mistakes i did. everytime i pass by, i will salute to the day i had the worst meal ive ever had in my adult life. thank you elysian for teaching me that lesson. you wont take another dime of my money.

So French. So, so French. This cafe (which is a sister restaurant with Amanda's just down the street) is a beautiful little spot to grab a weekend brunch and just relax.  The decor in the building is beautiful, with rich ornamentation and gorgeous cerulean walls. It was also surprisingly spacious since after seeing the outside seating, I imagined the indoors to be even smaller!The boyfriend and I were yet again on the brunch exploration. I ordered my staple: eggs florentine. And man, this place did it right. The hollandaise was creamy and tangy. The eggs were poached perfectly. The spinach delish. What was a bit different, however, was that it came with pommes frites instead of the more typical hash browns or home fries. When I bit into them, however, I didn't care. Those were some delicious French fries.After sipping some coffee for a while (also good), we got the bill which was meh. Not cheap, not expensive, right about where it should be. Not as fancy/gourmet as Amanda's, but it's cheaper and more laidback. A hardy yes to visiting this one again!
Great fries.  Mussels are tasty.  The Chocolate bread pudding is delicious.  The bar menu overall is good.  The brunch is pretty good. The outdoor seating is awesome.  Great overall atmosphere.
Amazing!!!!! Delicious!!!! Great service!!! Highly recommend it for brunch with the family!

Excellent food! We sat outside and it was a beautiful night. Lobster roll was great, as were the mussels in white wine sauce (PEI mussels...double positive!). Wine is affordable... the cheapest pino noir was light and delicious.Will absolutely go back. Dog friendly too!

Great brunch or dinner spot.  Sit outside if weather permits, nice corner location and garden-like feel.  Food is what you would expect at a decent bistro, it's good, not great.  Prices are ok overall.  The back room has some cool character and history.Avoid the bar area for dinner as it gets quite crowded and cramped at those tables.

I was excited to take my family here, but unfortunately, we had a really disappointing experience at the Elysian Cafe last night.Knowing it can get crowded on the weekends, we had walked in the night before to make reservations. The hostess wrote my name, time of reservations, and group number down on her pad of paper.On Saturday, we show up prior to our 7pm reservations. I approach the hostess and tell her we have reservations for five at 7pm. She immediately tells me they do not take reservations for fewer than six on Saturday nights. I explained to her I had not been informed of that policy and the hostess the night before had told us we were good to go. She tells me to wait and goes inside to get her manager. A couple minutes later, the manager walks out to speak with me explaining that they do not have record of me in their system and again, that they don't make reservations for less than six people. Rather than being apologetic or accommodating for the error, he continued to make excuses and push the blame onto me (and his hostess from the night before) for their mistake.  Not yet wanting to give up, I asked how long the wait was. He informed me there was no wait for the outside (it was getting chilly out), but a thirty minute wait for the inside because they "had reservations." Apparently the reservation I made the night before was not worth honoring or acknowledging. Annoyed with the lack of customer service and the manager's smugness, we decided to not give them our business.I can thank them though. We went elsewhere in Hoboken and had a lovely meal without the pretentiousness of the Elysian Cafe. I will probably never go back.

One of the best places for brunch in hoboken. The downside being the wait but theres plenty of seating at the bar to get your table. I had the Salmon eggs benedict which i always do over there its by far the best brunch item along with couple of mimosas adding on the perfect weather and outdoor seating made it for an awesome brunch.
With Anthony David's being as great as it is, Its easy to forget about Elysian. The grilled chicken sandwich is amazing.

The food was a step or two above McDonald's... Not fucking kidding. The ham that was on my croque Madame looked like spam and tasted like it was drowned in salt. Fries are exactly like McDonald's maybe worse. My girlfriends hanger steak and scrambled eggs looked somewhere between a continental breakfast and cafeteria food. Inedible steak once again drowned in salt and the eggs? Just lol. Don't be fooled by their nice prices because in reality it's expensive for how shitty the food actually is.

Wow, the bartenders are really, really douchy. I know that I am not a twice a week regular, but seriously, wife and I sat at the bar for a saturday 9pm dinner and got the most attitude, and most in-attentive service I have ever gotten.  The food is great, but if it served by a non-engaged brat than I don't see the point.  P.S. guys that's how you develop regulars that feed you a steady stream of great tips. There are plenty of places to spread the joy and money in Hoboken, Work Harder.

Great place for dinner in Hoboken, whether its for 2 or a small group of friends. Its a refreshing change from some of the other more generic "steakhouses" or "quick dinner" places that are found abundantly on Washington. If you are a foodie, dont miss it. I just recently went to celebrate my birthday there and I am very happy with that choice. It was easy to make reservations and they sat us right away. The service was good all night, they had 2 different people working our table to ensure we had everything we needed. Our waitress was very attentive and made some key recommendations for us. The ambience was probably one of my favorites and we werent even outside on the adorable patio surrounded by a lush garden on the sidewalks of hoboken. Food wise we had the crispy calamari salad (packed with flavor) and the goat cheese and beat salad (if you like those kinds of salads dont miss this one). Their Pomme Frites were definitely worth ordering. Dinners were a hit with everyone all around which included the salmon, seafood stew, and a few of the steak choices. Dont miss this place! I am sorry I have not gone there earlier, but happy I know how great it is now.

I live across the street from here - I am lucky to have such a great little restaurant so close to home! Even if I didn't live so close, I'd be a regular.The burger is my favorite burger in Hoboken, hands down. Super flavorful and juicy. Their fries seem to be laced with some sort of addictive magical ingredient because once you have one, you keep going! My girlfriend loves the crispy calamari salad.Elysian is also a great brunch spot. Have a mimosa or a bloody mary to start off your day. The salmon eggs benedict is great.Outdoor seating is great option that only adds to the charm of this place! Enjoy!

The food is 3 stars but the experience is at least four stars if you can get an outdoor table, especially on a sunny day. The brunch and lunch food is mainly standard fare done well enough. The beer selection is good too. In a city of brunch spots, Elysian doesn't stand out. If only Yelp allowed 3.5 stars.

It is not very French but pretends to be.It is pricey because it is in Hoboken, the setting is nice but the food is not great.The cheese platter was good but the waiter didnt even know what cheeses came with it.    My steak was over cooked and probably choice.Ok, so here is the breakdown, setting is very French, the staff is not informed to say the least.  Also, the prices higher than they should be considering the food quality.  The atmosphere is cool but overall a 2.5...I have been many great French places, including: Le Cirque, two greats in Vancouver: La Crocodile and Lumiere(which is not what it used to be after Rob Feenie left).

I'm still pissed off over New Year's Eve plans here from like six years ago.  I am not one for doing NYE up, but I felt like going out and celebrating, so my SO and I went, got dolled up and we had made reservations at Elysian a few weeks in advance.This place is where I decided that prix fixe NYE meals is just a rip off and that I will never ever go again.  No matter where.  Anyway, we paid something like $35/head but the kicker was that it was that we couldn't get the closer to midnight one (seating at 9:30 pm) so we opted for earlier seating (like 7:30 pm).  They made it clear no alcoholic beverages were included in the price, which was more than fine.  My SO didn't drink anyway.  I just wanted a glass of champagne. Here's the kicker though - soft drinks weren't  included either.  So if you wanted seltzer water - $3.  Two coffees?  Extra.  Soda?  extra.  It just absolutely killed me that they nickel and dimed EVERYTHING.  So by the time all was said and done, it ended up being $60/head on average.Oh but that wasn't all.  The food was absolutely disappointed.  Like "braised short rib?"  Yeah, if I wanted beef stew I would have just gone to my mom's for NYE.  We ordered a shrimp cauliflower bisque as our appetizer...it was 2 pieces of SMALL shrimp (to their credit, not "baby"), with a cauli puree over it.  I was all - what?  And the dessert was a chocolate peanut butter tart, which was a fancy phrase for "Giant Reese's Peanut Butter Cup."The best part?  After all was said and done?  As we walked home, I turned to my SO and said - are you still hungry?  He nodded emphatically.  We had to get Benny tudino's to go on the way home!  Ridick!  Spending $120 on overrated food and beverages (regardless of whether they were "adult") and then have to get pizza.  Yeah, I lived near Elysian for three years, and it left such a bad impression on me, I never returned.  I also made it a point the next year to just skip the hullabaloo and order from Benny's.  Now I just make my own dinner that night.

Why have I not reviewed Elysian?? The better half of the duo and I had lived across the street for years and have always made it our stop. Never a bad time, always a good drink -- Bubba, Josh ... even Aimes, most of the time -- you can not go wrong :)  So what if you had a bad burger one time here ... it will be fantastic next time. A talented kitchen makes it happen on a regular basis. I have sat in this restaurant countless times and still find new details that map me smile ... truly a great spot on the desolate crap-scape that is Hoboken restaurants.

Unless forced by aliens, I would not return to this restaurant.  I went there for dinner with a friend of mine on a Friday night.  I ordered the short ribs, she ordered the steak.  Neither of the meals were cooked properly.  My beef was full of fat, the onion rings were covered in oil, and the mashed potatoes had so much gravy on them that they lost their flavor.  McDonald's probably cooks with less oil than this place.There are PLENTY of other restaurants in Hoboken that offer better food and service for the money spent on mediocre food.

Service was excellent. Chicken Caesar salad was ok - dressing was tasty but the chicken seemed reheated.  French fries and croque Monsieur was great! Lovely little restaurant. Would definitely try brunch here as I hear it's wonderful.

I lived on this block 20 years ago.  I wish this place had been around back then.  What I like:Their happy hour, featuring 2 for 1 entrees from the bar menuCarlton 077XX IPA on tapTheir burgersThe lovely people from the neighborhood sitting at the bar with meWhat I didn't like:The somewhat unfriendly and unattentive bartender (a big, doughy, twentysomething kid)This bartender's awful music playing from his iPhone.  We are talking the hoariest of classic rock songs.  Like Kansas.  Yuck.But I'd go back for the burgers and Carlton IPA. :)
Great bartenders casual yet from atmosphere excellent food. And live music on Friday and Saturday evenings. You can't lose!

We stopped here randomly while visiting for a day. The decor was from another era - very 1930's France with marvelous ceilings and light cascading in from the windows. We had excellent French Onion soup, very decident Mac and cheese and some of the best corned beef hash I've ever had on a Ruben. Would highly recommend. Good outdoor seating, too.

I moved to Hoboken about five years ago, and had always been curious about Elysian Cafe.  The outdoor patio looked particularly inviting, and there never seemed to be an empty table whenever I would walk by.  My boyfriend and I were eager to give it a try, so we brought our healthy appetites over to Elysian for brunch.  Our server was friendly, and the steak and eggs were cooked perfectly.  So far, so good.Given how much I'd enjoyed my first experience at Elysian, I decided to put their dinner menu to the test.  I was just as impressed with their dinner selection as I was with their brunch menu - the steaks and truffle fries were delicious, and I ended up pairing the experience with a nice glass of wine and dessert.  It was surprising to see that they were just as busy during dinner as they were during brunch, as in my experience most restaurants only specialize in one meal.With that in mind, my boyfriend and I decided to stop by for lunch on his birthday.  What better way to celebrate?  Unfortunately, this is where Elysian fell short on its offerings.  We ordered a grilled chicken sandwich and a burger, which were both mediocre at best  --  and it didn't help that a baby at a nearby table vomited all over herself (and the table, and the floor).  Not really what comes to mind when you're looking to celebrate a special occasion!  The family was scrambling around to clean up, but I didn't see anyone else rushing over to help them.  I would have at least expected a manager or server to apologize for the disruption, but we were left to ourselves.That being said, I would still return for brunch or dinner...but I'm removing two stars for the disappointing lunch experience.

Here's a tip, fellas: girls LOOOOVE the Elysian Cafe. I don't know what it is--maybe the combination of fancy woodwork with modern elements, the neighborhood atmosphere with elevated food, or the cozy lighting and friendly staff--but every girl I know has fallen in love on the first visit.I tend to go on Monday nights for the two for one bar menu. Love the mussels and fries!

I went into Elysian Cafe today for lunch with four of my coworkers. We had never been here before so we decided to try it out . We were initially greeted at the bar by the bartender who threw out menus at us like if we were a bother to him for sitting at the bar . After ordering one of my favorites Stella Cider I continued to order my lunch. The bartender looked at us terribly with an attitude that I could not describe . I didn't understand what the problem was . I didn't want to stay there but our lunch break was beggining to cut short . My check came out to 14 dollars . I usually leave 20% or higher. I left him 5 dollars and left . He didn't deserve a tip at all after the way he treated us. I will never come to this establishment ever again.  Please find more personable servers and bartenders .

Went here for Sunday brunch with my girlfriend. It took a long time to get our order taken. I got the Croque Madame and she got Steak and Eggs. We waited about 30 minutes for our food to come out, and when it did, it was room temp. My sandwich could have been thrown together in a college dorm room, there was really nothing interesting or delicious about it. The french fries were literally MacDonald's fries, maybe even a little worse. My girlfriend's steak was tiny and well-done, even though she asked for it to be cooked medium. The potatoes that came with her meal were soggy and room temp, and there was only a small pile of them on her plate. We were still hungry when we left. Brass Rail is way better, we will not be back.

Always a line for Sunday brunch! Plan accordingly.If you don't mind the servers butchering the French language, but serve VERY tasty meals, then come here (at least for brunch).A little pricey for special brunch drinks, so steer clear unless you want a mimosa. Very cramped as well, though it may change when it's warmer outsideI had the steak and eggs... damn good steak and VERY GOOD MUSTARD. The bacon on the side is hard to top as well. All in all, if it weren't for the wait and the pronunciations, I'd say it was perfect.

Went today had the Lobster roll. It tasted and smelled fishy.  It had lettuce and tomato I thought that was strange. Also the bread was not toasted nor did it have mayo.  It was so bad I could not eat it after just 2 bites. The arugula and fries it came with was good. Had creme brûlée the shell was perfect, unfortunately the creme part was eggy.  Safely I would not go back.

I guess you can say this was a "pleasant surprise". We actually didn't know anyone who had heard of Elysian Cafe but wanted to go to Hoboken and basically stumbled on the place. Typical American bar setting. Dimly lit, small tables (a bit cramped especially when servers are taking orders next to you). But all in all, just basic food done well. French soup was legit (my girlfriend is a pro!). I had the Lobster Roll which was really good as well. Nice spot, nothing crazy, but would definitely go back.

This place reminds me of Cafe de Flore in Paris. In fact, every time I come here, I do not want to leave! Maybe it is the ambiance, with stained glass windows, damask-style wall relief, and their mahogany bar, what is not to like. I am certain the owner takes great pride in every detail they chose for this place - this intricacy is reflected in their food as well. Take their french onion soup, my brother tried this dish from every restaurant we went to in Montreal, then we came to Elysian and he exclaims it is the best he has ever had. Is it the broth, the crostini, or the cheese, I will never know. Yet, it is now six months later, and he still cannot stop talking about it. This is my favorite brunch in Hoboken, hands down. I think it was the fromage omelet that did it for me, but then there is also the salmon benedict. No, definitely the cinnamon-amaretto french toast. See, as I am recollecting all of this I am making myself hungry at 10:50 pm - now imagine yourself  "unwinding" from a great Friday night here. You may not even speak a word of French, and suddenly you will find yourself OOoouuu-ing and AAAahhh-ing. But be careful, there will be children in strollers around, so do try to be discrete about it. Honestly, I cannot think of a single reason why I have not come here for dinner. I bet it is just as good if not better than the brunch/lunch. This just reminded me to do just that!  This is owned by the same people who run Amanda's (and I've had dinner there) - I know I will not be disappointed!

I can only speak for the weekend brunch here. Thanks to fellow Yelpers, we chose Elysian Cafe to meet for a Sunday brunch. Charming cafe on the corner of Washington Street, it was great for us to sit outside to enjoy our meal. We met up quite late around 2 PM, so there was no wait at that time.Service was good as I arrived late and ordered my food after my friends, yet I received my dish minutes after my friends. Coincidentally, 3 of us got the Cinnamon-Amaretto French Toast with a berry sauce.  No complains about the toast.  My other friend had the burger, and he seemed to enjoy it.Definitely a spot to consider for a nice Hoboken weekend brunch.

This is, hands down, our favorite place in town. Delicious food, friendly staff, comfortable atmosphere. Great seafood, delish steak frites. The owners have two other nifty places in town too: Amanda's, for fancier occasions, and Schnackenberg's luncheonette for breakfast and lunch. The doughnuts at Schnackenberg's  are out of this world, and go there also to see the awesome mosaic made of tourist plates.

I absolutely love love love the bar menu here. Cute old fashioned french bistro feel to the interior and lots of outdoor seating. Their cocktails are strong and definitely worth the splurge. Everything on the bar menu is fairly priced and their french fries remind me of gourmet mcdonald's fries (in the best way possible, thin and extra salty). I got the pulled pork sandwich as usual and it was so overflowing i had to eat it with a fork! Love their coleslaw too. Their wait staff was very polite and quick with the orders, i will be coming back!

3.5 stars. Really lovely place for brunch (I haven't tried dinner). I wasn't blown away by anything here, but the dishes were well executed and the options and prices were good. My salmon eggs benedict was good but needed salt and pepper, particularly for the hollandaise (good texture but bland). The salmon was just okay - I think it could have been fresher, especially considering that every table I observed ordered at least one of the salmon benedict dishes. My friend's eggs florentine dish was similar - good but a bit bland. The lyonaisse potatoes (think thick potato chips that aren't super crispy) were nothing fabulous but were well prepared, and the pommes frittes were also good but underwhelming. I'll put it this way: everything was prepared properly, but USE SEASONING PEOPLE!!Service almost brought this up to 4 stars. The servers were attentive despite how busy they were and were on the ball.  We sat outside, which was hot since we were seated in the sun, although most people were shaded by umbrellas. The seats were wobbly and the tables were tightly packed outside, such that you were sitting with all of your neighbors and sharing your conversations. I suppose they were making the most of their space in a hoppin restaurant in Hoboken - I'll likely wait for an indoor table next time.I'd go back, but it wouldn't be my first choice.FYI: they won't take brunch reservations for less than 6 people.
Amazing brunch...the Bloody Mary's are out of this world (if you like it spicy ) and the bacon is the best I've ever had...no joke.....

I'm not really into the whole "brunch" culture so my review will naturally knock the Elysian down a few pegs. It's better straight up lunch and dinner. The service is much better for dinner as well. I will say that they have a solid menu. It won't blow you away but you won't be underwhelmed either. The prices for Hoboken are actually on the more reasonable side which is surprising considering the decor is upscale.I will say I've been dragged there a few times for brunch and the $3 champagne special is good but each time the service was sucky. Too many patrons and not enough service staff. Also way too many dogs and kids crammed in the outdoor section running around with parents sipping mimosas and not paying any attention to them. So I'm not going to say it's amazing but for Hoboken it ain't bad either.

Went prime time 2oclock on a Sunday 4 adults 1 child. (They are child friendly). There was a crowd gathered out front of maybe 8-10ppl but we were seated right away.  Outdoor seating, the inside seemed to have a little wait The outdoor cafe is beautiful we were seated under a magnificent tree and had plenty of shade. The brunch menu had something for everybody from lobster rolls and burgers to French Toast and different egg platters.  I got the chicken Caesar salad and was very impressed. Also picked at the fries I shared with my daughter. .so good soo good.The brunch drink options were very cheap, I got a screwdriver for less than 6$.Food came fast,  service with a smile and oh so tasty. Highly recommended I will be back!

Our go-to place for drinks and eats, since it first changed hands and went from dive bar to bistro. Food is excellent. Choice of beer and wine constantly changes and is always good, and the atmosphere is awesone. It can get crowded. Very. But that's because it's very good. Owners, Eugene and Joyce deserve a heaping plate of kudos for making it what it is today.

Since I have been coming to Hoboken I've passed the Elysian countless times and always thought "that place looks really cool, I want to try it sometime."  The location is up town and for the better part of my twenties I spent drowning in bud light and cheap whisky down town with the rest of the Goobahs, only now upon moving uptown have been able to sample the thing that has alluded me for so long.  The outdoor space is what they are known for and we were greeted warmly and told we could sit wherever we liked.  It was lunch time, we opted for outside and were pleasantly surprised by the menu.  Plenty of different options to choose from, but I would recommend the half and half.  It's a half sandwich and soup or salad.  I was concerned the portion might be too small but it was very satisfying.  The smoked salmon club was delicious and was filled to capacity with fresh fish.  Craft cocktails are always a plus in my book and they were well balanced and tasty.  Service was friendly and polite and the food was served hot and promptly.  This place fills up FAST, so perhaps a call head is worth it just to make sure they have tables available.  Took me a while to get here but I'll for sure be back.

Ive been going to Elysian for five years its my goto for food or drinks. The menu has a  something for everyone and the food is consistently great. Ive been for Brunch, dinner and order from the bar menu often. The warm roast beef sandwich is a winner. The service is friendly and the bartenders are very attentive which is a not as  common as one would think in hoboken. If your looking for something other than the cookie cutter bar food in town this is the place for you.

I finally had the pleasure of stopping by here and experiencing brunch with a new friend. The wait staff who attended to us were super friendly & attentive. The decor inside the place is pretty nice.For the time that we arrived - at around 11:30am on a Saturday, the place had quite a bit of open seating which was nice. It filled up quickly and by around 1pm the front section of the cafe was completely packed and became a little bustling. I had the cinnamon french toast w/ a bacon side with a cappuccino and enjoyed both profusely. Very scrumptious.Prices are just right. I wasn't sweating at all over the bill!

I really like this place.  It's a French cafe and the food is not expensive but yummy.  The place is a little rustic.  They have beautiful fixtures, and you feel like you are in a building that was once really upscale, except they go for a rundown antique look.  Their pomme frites are really good.  And they do a great brunch on weekends.What really put this place over for me is that they have a really cute outdoor area and they allow dogs!  We have been to brunch a few times and they will let us keep our puppy under the table and even bring her water.  Hoboken is very dog friendly and it's nice to be able to eat out while walking the dog.

one of the best in hoboken, hands down. after being skeptical of hobo restaurants due to their abundance of sub par food, i had low expectations for elysian. but i have to say, i was so pleasantly surprised with the quality of food. everything i've had there has been delicious and cooked perfectly, especially their salmon. service is good, if you want to have a long dinner, they leave you alone and don't push you out the door. i would definitely recommend coming here.

Well I'm finally here.. Been passing this place for years....Staff seems nice and accommodating.. It's a lot of people here for brunch ...I had the steak and eggs  with a side of bacon... The fries came out room temp. If not cold... Steak wasn't what I thought it should be and they messed of the temp. I wanted. But my bacon was perfect !!! Thick, crips and meaty.I would come back again and try dinner before I rule them out...

Shoot me now. Hoboken Brunch is already a fail but decided to treck here since it was one of the top rated ones in Hoboken.  What a dissapointment right from putting our name in -- Hostess forgot it twice and we waited twice as long to get a table-probably waited longer than we actually spent in there. So, the premise of this review is that we had a bad start. THey DID get us free mimosas to make up for this mishap, that was a good move, thank you.Food is pretty darn cheap here for brunch so I'll give them that. Settled on the salmon eggs benedict--it was just meh, whatever. Such a sad sad plating of the dish since the Fries bucket dominated the plate. Highlight of the food was probably the fries which tasted like McDonalds but I"m gonna go out on a whim and say they were the frozen kind.Recommendation: try any other place in Hoboken and forget bout this spot.  Even some sports bars have better food/selection.  If I'm caught getting brunch in HB again it'll be at Sabores or La Isla.

Came for Brunch on a Sunday around noon, they were super busy. 20 minute wait for outside seating, little to no wait inside.The service was fast but some servers were a little disheveled. the interior is really awesome, reminiscent of a 1940's French bar, very ornate ceiling fixtures & trim, vintage mosaic tile floor. This must be a great place to hang out in, late at night, listening to Serge Gainsbourg sipping on an old fashioned or something French.I ordered the Egg white omelette, with spinach, tomato & goat cheese with pommes frittes, the eggs were fluffy but a little greasy, they could have put a little more goat cheese, the fries were awesome. I also ordered the cafe creme, very good flavor and fresh.My fiancee ordered, blueberry pancakes, really sweet and tart, not sure if they used fresh blueberries, I recommend ordering the bacon "well done," she got it perfectly cooked but another person in our group did not order it that way and it was greasy and flappy.My one gripe is that when we ask for some butter, they brought out little butter pre-wrapped butter squares and not a small tin of fresh/whipped butter. Seems like a dumb thing to ask for, but it's just a small detail that shouldn't be overlooked in a French bistroWith 4 entrees, 1 mimosa, 2 coffees & 1 OJ, it came out to $70 with tip & we left full.Great experience, will return for dinner at least once.

An awesome place to have dessert and an after dinner drink. Upscale decor with a casual vibe. They have live music on Friday and Saturday and a TV at the bar. There wasn't anything I didn't like about this place, though the bartenders in t-shirts kind of stood out from their environment. Definetely will be back.

The food was okay and the location was great. I like the ambiance. However, the service was poor. We wanted to order drinks at the bar while we wait for our table and took a couple of minutes before we got the drinks menu. The mimosa I ordered was not even in a champagne glass!!!! The waiter was not friendly, he barely said anything other than what we wanted, never recommended anything on the menu and he seemed really disconnected!!! If I had a great service a 5 star would have been appropriate.

Catching up on some older visits...but from what I remember Brunch was fantastic, It was pretty simple brunch food and they don't try to be all trendy like other places in the area. I literally had one of of these trendy cafes in the area make me a grilled cheese with muenster cheese, applewood bacon on french toast ciabatta bread...c'mon "we get it, you're different"! But not this place, the food was made like it should be, classic and usual. I was drinking Margaritas like they were going out of style and they were awesome! The bartenders were very attentive but not as personable for my liking, then again, the bar was packed. The only other thing I want to comment on is the confusion of waiting...almost always a wait, one line...but you never know if that que is for a table inside, the outdoor seating or the bar itself...we usually just bypass the line and go straight to the bar...so far no one has ever said anything to us, so I don't think we are doing anything wrong or inconsiderate. Also be prepared to walk a few blocks after finally finding a parking spot....it is Hoboken after all. Very mixed clientele which is nice, and the place always seems exceptionally clean with great decor.

My rating for Elysian Cafe is strictly for the outside seating during brunch.  The inside is incredibly cramped usually, but the outside seating is perfect for an enjoyable meal.  They have reasonably priced breakfast items with nice cafe style seating (I've also had lunch here as well, but it wasn't spectacular).  The service is fine, but the food and the atmosphere for brunch really make this place worth an occasional visit.

Happy hour is just a lil' bit happier at Elysian. Especially on Mondays. Why, you ask? Because from 5-7 p.m. in the bar, it's a compounded special time with their HH (half-price house wine, beer and cocktails) AND their Monday night 2-4-1 bar entree deal. That's like, a middle manager's salary worth of discount.Their house wine includes any $7 glass on the menu, so it  gives you more of a choice than the typical one white and one red that I'm used to. I had the sauvignon blanc for my first glass, but soon switched over to the vinho verde after a sip of my BFF's glass. And the bartenders betrayed no judgment when we drank our way through the good part of a bottle and a half of that crisp, summery Portuguese wine... at $3.50 per glass.For eats, we shared the mussels/frites and the calamari. I'd recommend the calamari in a heartbeat.The calamari is so crispy and seasoned perfectly, with kalamata olives, tomato and arugula on top. So it's almost a salad, right? A fat salad. The mussels were tasty too, but I wasn't that impressed with the frites. The French menu isn't fancy French---just regular person French. That carries on in the vintage decor and atmosphere as well. There's a corner sidewalk patio, a casual bar area and a slightly nicer dining area. Though it's ornately decorated, none of it's stuffy.Other Tips:1. This Monday night entree deal is listed as a winter thing only on their website, but we got it on Memorial Day so I don't know.2. The bartenders were awesome, but two of the other staff members who greeted us were not very helpful when we directly asked them if happy hour is only in the bar area (it was). They were just like, "Sit wherever you want..." So we did, and then the wait assistant let us know that HH is just in the bar... so we moved.3. If you snag a coveted bar seat on a bright and sunshiney day, make sure to bring a hat or slather on the sunscreen on the back of your neck---the UV rays come pouring in right on top of your head at sunset.

Had a reservation for six people on a Saturday. The hostess called me to confirm that at 3pm the brunch had ended and the only menu available would be the bar menu. The food choices were still excellent! Everyone enjoyed their food (salmon and cream cheese sandwhich, grilled chicken sandwhich, fish and chips...) and Dad was even happy because they had Coors Banquet (thank goodness!). Drink selection is very good as well. The restaurant is perfect for brunch or lunch with friends or family. The history and decor of the place adds something special. Will definitely be back.

Really, really good brunch/lunch.  We sat in the beautiful outdoor dining area and enjoyed the people watching and summer air (sappy, I know).  We had lobster roll (delicious, but small and pricey) and grilled chicken sandwiches, which were excellent.  Looking forward to coming back.Downside(s):  Service was ok, but not as attentive as we would have liked; Coffee was mediocre.

I went over the summer and sat outdoors, which was wonderful! The table and chairs remind me of a quaint Parisian restaurant. The food was great (I had the crêpe du jour, which was short ribs and gruyere, and it tasted fabulous) and the service was very good as well! Definitely recommend.

Pretty standard option for brunch on the weekends. Steak and eggs are my usual go-to but the steak can be hit or miss with temperature. I think they have good portions for the price. In the past, I've found that their chicken sandwich is always on point, great portion and served with either a salad or fries. Be prepared to wait for a table on the weekend, especially around brunch time. For a crowded place the waitstaff is pretty attentive. I've had the same waitress every time I've been here and she's good (checks in after food arrives, refills drinks etc).

BORING, BORING, BORING.Does this restauranteur have any idea of the meaning of a season?  Or even a special?  The food is adequate - nothing to write home about.  But is is always exactly the same.  In a town with amazing bread, why don't they serve it???Nice atmosphere and pretty to sit outside but I am soooooo sick of the same exact menu month after month, year after year.  Total and complete lack of innovation or creativity.  I guess this is why Hoboken has a rep for lowest common denominator cuisine.

I can't say enough about how much I enjoy meals and drinks at the Elysian. The food is always on point, in that it's delicious and it's consistently good. The Monday 2 for 1 special can not be beat. Buy one item from the bar menu get the 2nd FREE. They also have a great steak dinner deal Wednesdays for $20. I love the bar, brunch etc. All of the staff is friendly and accommodating and all in all, I love the Elysian.

Cream of the crop in Hoboken, been twice so far and both times the food was memorable.In terms of atmosphere, relaxing despite it being very busy on Friday nights.  Front bar is bustling, with people at the bar drinking and having meals, with tables along the windows to seat 3-4.  Fairly easy to get a drink despite being crowded, bar tenders were nice enough.  Staff in general are pretty nice, hostesses more so.First time got the chipotle strip steak with (I believe) sides of asparagus and risotto (mushroom if i recall).  It was very good, wouldn't say its NYC steakhouse good but great value for price.  Also got the braised pork over (i believe) mashed potatoes, very nice!  Appetizer, MUST GET the mussels in either white or red sauce, comes with fantastic fries (sort of McDonald's style - thin, crispy, salted appropriately).  Second time got the pork chop (on menu), which was prepared more like a breaded veal fillet with a very generous helping of arugula salad, balsamic, and creamy potatoes - may sound odd but immediately a top 10 Hoboken dish, amazing.Last point, first time got the mint chocolate chip ice cream sundae, perfection!

I'm probably a little biased: I've just moved to a fantastic apartment in Hoboken, and this was the first place I ate while I was hunting for housing, so it instantly acquired sentimental value that will no doubt only increase in time (since I now live two blocks away).That said, I've gone back twice now, and I've loved everything I've eaten there.  The Warm Roast Beef au poivre sandwich is delicious and the garlic fries are awesome.  I had a chicken special the third time I went (and I'm doing them a disservice by not recalling the name).  It was stuffed with light amounts of cheese and garlic and was perfectly cooked.  The atmosphere is very nice.  The TV above the bar played a soccer game on Telemundo, which was slightly out of joint with the rest of the arch Victorian detailing, but I'm going to give them a pass on that.  The TV wasn't a dominating presence in the room.  Their wait staff has impressed me every time I went; last time we were there our waitress was Vanessa, and she was terrific.  At the end of the day, I can't say enough good about the place.  I'm looking forward to it becoming my local watering hole and go-to cafe when I just don't feel like cooking.

Sunday was the first time I enjoyed brunch in Hoboken and I heard Elysian was the place to go! I wish it was a better day to enjoy their outdoor seating but the inside was BEAUTIFUL! We easily found a spot at the bar even though the wait wasn't long. The regulars were super nice and made room for us. The bartender was nice though we were serviced more by the bar back then the bartender. Whenever I check out a brunch place for the first time I always judge the place by the benedict. Their benedict was good, one of my eggs was perfectly cooked, but the other one was way over done. But really no complaints and understandable - Silly poached eggs...My P.I.C. ordered the Cinnamon- Amaretto French Toast with a strawberry sauce. We both agreed it was good, little too much strawberry sauce but we liked the idea!We'll defiantly be back soon- there are few more items I want to try on their menu. Plus the website reads $20 Steak nights on Wednesdays! Um- Yes, please!

Great spot for brunch. Came here for a private party in the back room. It is so charming with fantastic architectural details. Thr mimosas were great. I had a watercress salad with lardons and goat cheese - quite yummy! And I had he chicken with bacon and avocado sandwich on foccacia bread - double yum! To finish I had the apple cinnamon pain perdu, it was fantastic. This place is a winner in my book!
Took my family to the Elysian Cafe about a month ago. Food and service were superb. A bit expensive but well worth it
Loved this place!We went on a Friday lunchtime and we absolutely loved the atmosphere, food and the service. Will definitely come back here to try another food! =)

What a nice find. Had a late lunch here with the family and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The place is tastefully decorated in a warm, vintage style. Make sure your check out the ceiling in the bar area -- it's beautiful. The waitstaff was friendly and attentive. (My 14-year-old daughter thought the waiter was "dreamy.")The food was very tasty and freshly prepared. The mac and cheese, the grilled rueben, the croque-monsieur and the sausage and pepper crepes were all outstanding. Nothing frozen or processed here. Don't pass on the Pommes frites. They're some of the best fries I've ever tasted. The prices were great considering what we got for our money. We even opted for desert (which we rarely do) and were very satisfied. This place is an instant favorite! We'll be back for sure.

I feel the need to post a good comment since I have trashed so many places in Hoboken.  The Elysian, like its sister resturant Amandas are both amazing.  The food is very good and constant and the atmosphere in both are very warm and welcoming.  Probable the best 2 resturants in Hoboken outside of Dino's.  A must try.  Its worth the wait at eiher.
very cute place, easy to spend sometime chatting with a friend and food is one of the best in Hoboken. My fav in the area

Our strongest memory of eating at the Elysian will be leaving with stomach cramps. Two of us dined at the Elysian Cafe after having only moved to the area. We ate on a Monday evening, drawn by the possibility of eating outside on the sidewalk. Added bonus - the Elysian offers 2-for-1 dishes on their bar menu. Or, do they.....read on.We ordered 2 things from the bar menu (only so we could have the 2-for-1) -- the French onion soup and the garlic fries. The French onion soup was passable, but the garlic fries were pretty ordinary.For small entrees, we had the grilled octopus, mac-n-cheese, and arugula salad.The mac-n-cheese was decent, but nothing remarkable.The arugula salad -- well, let's use air quotes around the word arugula here. The greens were dried out and starting to turn. The goat cheese was dumped straight from a plastic pouch. And the beets were sliced straight OUT OF A CAN. CANNED BEETS, what!?The octopus was overcooked, tough, and bland. And, gave us tummy aches.Then, when we're already just disappointed, we get the bill and there is an error. We politely tell the server that she has charged us for both of our bar items, even though it's Monday and they should be 2-for-1. She says that only SOME of the bar items are involved with that special. We did make a small stink about this, asking her to clarify which items were part of the special and which weren't, and she didn't seem to care about explaining this to us, and certainly did not make an offer to make us happy.We will NEVER come here again. Awful, boring, bland food for awful, boring, bland people.

I wish I went to Elysian sooner than I had. It's French and I don't like French food, so I was always turned off. Boy, did I have it wrong. Elysian is amazing! Never had a bad meal here. I adore their lobster roll, something you don't find very often in Hoboken, at least a good one! They also serve fresh oysters, another hard find in the Mile Square City. Other tasty items here include the roast beef and chicken sandwiches. Their fries are addictive. They have a pretty extensive menu, even during brunch, when many establishments usually serve a limited menu. Drinks always aim please and the bartenders are always so pleasant. They have some great specials, including Monday nights, when their bar menu is buy one get one free. The ambiance is quaint and there is usually a crowd. In the spring and summer, it's one of the prettiest places on Washington Street to eat, drink and people watch. Good for friends or date night, Elysian is a winner.

I've been here multiple times for brunch (not sure why it's taken me so long to write a review for them!). I really enjoy the eggs benedict here which is what I always get when I come. I've also tried the amaretto french toast - super deelish but a bit heavy. We almost always get the same server and he always provides great service. My only complaint is that the food never comes out piping hot the way I like it. On at least one ocassion I've had to send it back and ask them to heat it up some more. They actually replaced the dish and made sure it was hot which I appreciated. One quick tip: get the pommes frites instead of the home fries - you (but not your waistline) will thank me later!
